body.para:
I tried installing the Jalopy module the way the web site describes and it
fails. Here are the errors I'm seeing:

The module named org.openide.deprecated was needed and not found. No module providing the capability org.openide.compiler.CompilationEngine could
be found. The module named org.openide.execution.deprecated was needed and not found. The module named org.openide.compiler was needed and not found. No module providing the capability org.openide.TopManager could be found.

quote.quotepara: -----Original Message----- From: Mark Claassen [mailto:mclaassen@ocie.net] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 1:01 PM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine

You can use ctrl-shift-f to reformat the whole file...fixing the
inconsistencies. Unfortunately, if you do this you will get the "} else {" thing. I don't know of anyway to have nb do this to more than one file at a
time though. Maybe you will have to use Jalopy to clean things up.
Good luck!

quote.quotepara: -----Original Message----- From: David Barron [mailto:David.Barron@sas.com] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 11:53 AM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine

Yes I've done that and that is what causes the mix of spaces and tabs that I'm
getting now.
-----Original Message----- From: Mark Claassen [mailto:mclaassen@ocie.net] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 12:35 PM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine

However, you are in a bit of luck. I rather use tabs as well, and there is a
setting in: Tools -> Options -> Editors -> Editor Settings -> Java Editor -> Java
Indentation Engine for just this. Uncheck the "Expand tabs to spaces" box
-----Original Message----- From: David Barron [mailto:David.Barron@sas.com] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 11:01 AM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine
That's an option, but wouldn't it be better to be able to configure the editor? Or am I asking too much.
-----Original Message----- From: Reed, Brent [mailto:reedb@byui.edu] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 10:52 AM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine
No, it only runs when invoked.
-----Original Message----- From: David Barron [mailto:David.Barron@sas.com] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 8:48 AM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: RE: [nbusers] Java indent engine

Does jalopy control indentation while editing the way the Java Indentation
Engine does?
-----Original Message----- From: netbeans@claudius.com.br [mailto:netbeans@claudius.com.br] Sent: Friday, August 19, 2005 10:32 AM To: nbusers@netbeans.org Subject: Re: [nbusers] Java indent engine

Take a look at Jalopy plugin, available at
http://contrib.netbeans.org/servlets/ProjectDocumentList and search for
"jalopy-plugin-netbeans-java5.nbm", download and install it. The Jalopy options is locate at: Tools menu --> Jalopy options -->
Indentation --> Misc (tab) --> check "Use tabs to indent"
Claudio Miranda
On Fri, 19 Aug 2005 09:41:58 -0400, "David Barron" <David.Barron@sas.com> escreveu:

I really enjoy working with NetBeans, especially since 4.1 has been released. Very solid and extremely easy to use. However, there is one thing about Eclipse that I prefer and that's the indent engine. I'm one of those weird programmers who prefers to indent with
tabs instead of spaces. Yes yes, I know, it's not according to the standard,
but indenting with tabs looks much more consistant from one editor to another.

Anyway, Eclipse allows me to indent with only tabs if I choose to. In the NetBeans Java Indent Engine the only option I have is to turn off "Expand
Tabs to Spaces" and if I do this I end up with a bizare mix of tabs and spaces
in the indentations. This looks ok in NetBeans, as long as I don't look to
closely, but if I load the file into another editor, TextPad for example, the
indentations end up all over the place. Not good.

Is there ANY way to use only tabs for indents in NetBeans? I'd even be willing to rebuild from source if someone has any advice on where to make the
changes.
Cordialmente
